Objective: Understand what classification is and why it is important.
Content:
- Definition of classification.
- Importance: Organizing things to understand them better.
Activities: - Group objects from the classroom (e.g., books, pencils, plants) and discuss similarities/differences.

Lesson Title: Characteristics of Living and Non-Living Things
Objective: Learn the differences between living and non-living things.
Content:
- Living things: Grow, reproduce, need food, and respond to the environment.
- Non-living things: Do not grow, reproduce, or need food.
Activities: - Observe a live plant and compare it with a plastic plant. Discuss differences.

Objective: Explore methods of classification.
Content: - Using observable characteristics (e.g., size, shape, color).
Activities: - Sort objects into groups based on size or color.

Objective: Learn how to visually represent classification.
Content: - Charts and tables for classification.
Activities: - Create a simple chart classifying items as "Living" or "Non-Living."

Objective: Understand what plants are and where they can be found.
Content:
- Definition of plants and their habitats.
- Examples: Forests, gardens, deserts, water.
Activities: - Discuss places students have seen plants and create a list.

Objective: Learn how plants are classified based on characteristics.
Content: - Classification: Flowering vs. non-flowering, size, and habitat.
Activities: - Observe a flowering plant and a fern, noting differences.

Objective: Compare plants to understand similarities and differences.
Content:
- Similarities: All plants make food through photosynthesis.
- Differences: Size, leaf shape, flowers, fruits.
Activities: - Match pictures of plants to their characteristics.

Objective: Explore why plants are important.
Content: - Provide oxygen, food, habitat, and prevent soil erosion.
Activities: - Brainstorm ways plants are used in daily life.

Objective: Learn about the different kinds of animals around us.
Content: - Examples of animals: Mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, fish, insects.
Activities: - Show pictures of animals and discuss their characteristics.

Objective: Understand how animals are grouped.
Content: - Classification based on physical features and behavior (e.g., mammals give birth to live young).
Activities: - Group pictures of animals into mammals, birds, reptiles, etc.

Objective: Discover the importance of animals to humans and the environment.
Content: - Provide food, pollinate plants, maintain ecological balance.
Activities: - Discuss animals' roles in everyday life and their habitats.

Objective: Understand how animals adapt to survive in their environments.
Content: - Examples: Camouflage, sharp teeth, webbed feet.
Activities: - Use toys or models to demonstrate how animals blend into their habitats.

Objective: Learn about fungi and where they can be found.
Content: - Fungi: Non-green organisms that grow on decaying matter (e.g., mushrooms, mold).
Activities: - Observe mold growth on bread kept in moist conditions.

Objective: Explore bacteria and their characteristics.
Content:
- Microscopic organisms found everywhere.
- Harmful bacteria: Cause diseases.
- Helpful bacteria: Aid digestion, make food (e.g., yogurt).
Activities: - Discuss examples of helpful and harmful bacteria.

Objective: Recap all topics and assess understanding of Units 3.1.1 to 3.1.4.
Content: - Review key concepts through a trivia game or group discussion.
Activities: - Conduct Intermediate Test.

Objective: Understand what materials are and identify different types of materials.
Content:
- Definition of materials.
- Types: Wood, metal, plastic, glass, fabric, and rubber.
Activities: - Students observe and classify classroom objects based on their materials.

Objective: Explore how materials differ in properties.
Content: - Properties: Strength, flexibility, transparency, water resistance.
Activities: - Test materials for flexibility using objects (e.g., a plastic ruler, metal spoon, paper).

Objective: Learn what a fair test is and why it is important.
Content:
- Fair test: Only one variable is changed while others are kept constant.
- Example: Testing the strength of materials using equal-sized samples.
Activities: - Discuss scenarios where a test is fair or unfair, and how to ensure fairness.

Objective: Conduct fair tests to investigate material properties.
Content: - Focus on testing water resistance and transparency.
Activities:
- Water resistance: Drop water on fabric, plastic, and paper and observe absorption.
- Transparency: Hold materials (glass, paper, fabric) up to light to observe visibility.

Lesson Title: How Materials Are Chosen for Objects
Objective: Understand why specific materials are used for certain objects.
Content: - Objects are made from materials based on their properties (e.g., glass for windows, rubber for tires).
Activities: - Match objects to materials based on their properties (e.g., "Why is a raincoat made of plastic?").

Lesson Title: Recap and Practical Application of Materials
Objective: Review key concepts and discuss the practical use of materials in daily life.
Content:
- Summary of material types and properties.
- Real-life applications: Furniture, clothing, tools.
Activities: - Group discussion on how material choices affect the environment (e.g., plastic vs. paper bags).

Objective: Assess understanding of Unit 3.2 and reinforce learning.
Content: - Address questions from the test and clarify doubts.
Activities: - Conduct Intermediate Test covering 3.2.

Topic: Your Amazing Body as a System
Objective: Understand what a system is and identify examples of systems.
Content:
- A system: A group of parts working together for a common purpose.
- Examples: Car engine, school system, human body.
Activities: - Discuss and identify systems in daily life, such as a car or a classroom.

Topic: Your Amazing Body as a System
Lesson Title: Introduction to the Human Body as a System
Objective: Learn how the body functions as a system.
Content:
- The human body is made up of different organ systems working together.
- Overview of major organ systems (e.g., circulatory, respiratory, digestive).
Activities: - Use a diagram of the human body to point out and name organ systems.

Topic: Your Amazing Body as a System
Objective: Identify key organ systems and their roles.
Content:
- Circulatory system: Transports oxygen and nutrients.
- Respiratory system: Provides oxygen and removes carbon dioxide.
- Digestive system: Breaks down food into nutrients.
Activities: - Match organs to their respective systems using flashcards or a worksheet.

Topic: Your Amazing Body as a System
Objective: Explore how organ systems interact to keep the body functioning.
Content:
- Example: The respiratory system provides oxygen to the circulatory system.
- The digestive system provides nutrients that the circulatory system transports.
Activities: - Create a simple flowchart showing the interaction between two systems.

Topic: Your Amazing Body as a System
Lesson Title: The Digestive System – Overview and Function
Objective: Learn the parts and function of the digestive system.
Content:
- Major parts: Mouth, esophagus, stomach, intestines.
- Function: Breaks down food into nutrients and removes waste.
Activities: - Use crackers and water to simulate digestion in the mouth (chewing and saliva).

Topic: Your Amazing Body as a System
Objective: Explore the process of digestion in detail.
Content:
- Steps in digestion: Ingestion, digestion, absorption, excretion.
- Role of enzymes and stomach acids.
Activities: - Use a visual aid to show the journey of food through the digestive tract.

Topic: Your Amazing Body as a System
Lesson Title: Recap and Real-Life Application of Body Systems
Objective: Review the functions of organ systems and discuss their importance.
Content:
- Summary of organ systems and their interactions.
- Importance of maintaining a healthy body through proper nutrition and exercise.
Activities: - Group discussion on healthy habits for keeping organ systems functioning properly.

Topic: Your Amazing Body as a System
Objective: Assess understanding of Unit 3.3 and address any misconceptions.
Content: - Clarify doubts and summarize key concepts through a trivia game.
Activities: - Conduct Intermediate Test covering Unit 3.3.

Lesson Title: Introduction to the Parts of a Plant
Objective: Identify the different parts of a plant.
Content: - Parts: Roots, stem, leaves, flowers, and fruits.
Activities: - Examine a real or model plant and name its parts.

Objective: Learn the role of roots in keeping the plant alive.
Content: - Functions: Absorbing water and nutrients, anchoring the plant in the soil.
Activities: - Place a plant with roots in colored water to observe how roots absorb water.

Objective: Understand the function of the stem.
Content: - Functions: Transports water and nutrients between roots and leaves, supports the plant.
Activities: - Use celery or a white flower in colored water to observe how the stem transports water.

Objective: Explore the role of leaves in keeping the plant alive.
Content: - Functions: Photosynthesis (making food), releasing oxygen, and transpiration.
Activities: - Show stomata using a magnifying lens.

Objective: Learn the role of flowers and fruits in the life cycle of a plant.
Content:
- Flowers: Attract pollinators, help in reproduction.
- Fruits: Protect seeds and help in seed dispersal.
Activities: - Discuss and observe different flowers and fruits, noting their colors, shapes, and uses.

Objective: Understand how different parts of a plant work together to keep it alive.
Content: - Roots absorb water → Stem transports water → Leaves make food → Flowers produce seeds.
Activities: - Create a flowchart showing the interaction of plant parts.

Objective: Assess understanding of Unit 3.4 and reinforce key concepts.
Content: - Review key concepts through a trivia game or group discussion.
Activities: - Conduct Intermediate Test covering Unit 3.4.

Topic: Magnets, Their Characteristics, and Making Magnets
Objective: Understand what a magnet is and identify some common magnets.
Content:
- Definition of a magnet.
- Examples: Bar magnet, horseshoe magnet, refrigerator magnets.
Activities:
- Show students different types of magnets and discuss where they might have seen them.
- Use a magnet to attract small metal objects (e.g., paper clips, pins).

Topic: Magnets, Their Characteristics, and Making Magnets
Objective: Explore the characteristics of magnets.
Content:
- Magnets attract certain materials (e.g., iron, steel) and repel like poles.
- Magnetic poles: North and South.
Activities:
- Test which materials (e.g., plastic, wood, iron) are attracted to a magnet.
- Use two magnets to demonstrate attraction and repulsion between poles.

Topic: Magnets, Their Characteristics, and Making Magnets
Lesson Title: Uses of Magnets in Everyday Objects
Objective: Learn about the uses of magnets in everyday life.
Content: - Uses: Fridge magnets, magnetic clasps, compasses, and motors.
Activities:
- Brainstorm examples of objects that use magnets and discuss their functions.
- Show a compass and explain how magnets are used to determine direction.

Topic: Magnets, Their Characteristics, and Making Magnets
Objective: Understand how magnets can be made.
Content: - Methods: Stroking a magnet, using an electric current, and inducing magnetism.
Activities: - Make a simple magnet by stroking a piece of iron or steel (e.g., a nail) with a bar magnet.

Topic: Magnets, Their Characteristics, and Making Magnets
Objective: Learn how electromagnets are made and their uses.
Content:
- How to make an electromagnet: Wrapping a wire around an iron nail and connecting it to a battery.
- Uses: Cranes in scrap yards, electric bells, and speakers.
Activities: - Create a simple electromagnet using a nail, wire, and battery, and test its strength.

Topic: Magnets, Their Characteristics, and Making Magnets
Objective: Review the characteristics and applications of magnets.
Content: - Summary of magnetic properties, uses, and how magnets are made.
Activities: - Create a chart summarizing the uses of magnets and electromagnets.

Topic: Magnets, Their Characteristics, and Making Magnets
Objective: Assess understanding of Units 3.5.1 and 3.5.2 and clarify any doubts.
Content: - Discuss test results and address misconceptions.
Activities: - Conduct Intermediate Test covering Units 3.5.1 and 3.5.2.
